repnme.cdata!: Uganda - Northern Uganda Social Action Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Northern Uganda Social
            Action Fund (NUSAF) Project for Uganda were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: transparency and accountability
            can be a challenge in hard-to-reach areas. However,
            participatory involvement of communities in sub-project
            management, public sharing of expenditures at the local
            level and follow-up on misuse of funds resulted in improved
            accountability and transparency. NUSAF 2 aims to further
            strengthen bottom-up accountability through the TAAC
            (transparency, accountability, and anti-corruption)
            subcomponent. One of the key lessons from this project is
            the challenge of targeting transient/nomadic communities.
            For this reason, and with the exception of subprojects that
            were implemented through the missionary Non-Governmental
            Organizations (NGOs), the Karamoja sub-region remained a
            challenge throughout the life of the project. Placement of
            the executing agency under the Office of the Prime Minister
            (OPM) made difficult decision-making processes possible,
            allowed for mediation between local governments, and
            facilitated the flexible approach to project implementation.
            For instance, the Youth Opportunities Program (YOP)
            randomized experimental design is likely to deliver robust
            lessons that can be used in other regions with similar youth
            unemployment challenges.

repnme.cdata!: Uganda - Northern Uganda Social Action Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Northern Uganda Social Action Fund
            Project aims to empower communities in Northern Uganda by
            enhancing their capacity to systematically identify,
            prioritize, and plan for their needs and implement
            sustainable development initiatives that improve
            socio-economic services and opportunities. The project
            consists of four components. The community demand initiative
            component will support community-driven initiatives that
            improve the accessibility to and the delivery of small-scale
            socio-economic services and enhance the capacity of
            communities and other stakeholders involved in the process.
            The vulnerable group support component will identify the
            vulnerable groups and Civil Society Organizations,
            nongovernmental organizations, and private sector agencies
            in order to develop strategies likely to contribute to their
            poverty alleviation. The third component will provide
            support and encourage communities to identify innovative
            ways for community reconciliation and conflict management
            using traditional and non-traditional approaches, base on
            indigenous knowledge, the way communities have in the past
            managed conflict so that it has not led to open warfare, and
            helping communities reclaim this knowledge for use in
            modern-day living in Uganda. The institutional development
            component will support training and capacity building for
            different sets of stakeholders. It will also support
            activities to inform and educate the concerned stakeholders
            on the project objectives, processes an

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Second Northern Uganda
            Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This environment impact assessment (EIA)
            for the Second Northern Uganda Reconstruction Project
            consisted of screening to determine if the project hah
            significant impacts. Because this project was determined not
            to have the potential to have significant environmental
            impacts, it is excluded from further environmental impact
            assessment. However, this report contains recommendations to
            the developer for sound environmental management of the
            project, as is customary for projects in this category. As
            this project is classified as a Financial Intermediary
            Project (FI), any activites which might violate World Bank
            safeguard policies have to be identified. Accordingly, what
            follows is a summation of an analysis of relevant safeguard
            policies: This project will put in place in place and EA
            framework for the sub-projects cycle to ensure environmental
            awareness and compliance. Subprojects supporting protection
            and maintenance of natural habitats will be funded. Possible
            subprojects might address pest control and rodent extinction
            for sanitary reasons. DDT can potentially be procured, e.g.,
            for malaria vector control. Cumulative effects of
            deforestation due to brick-burning, charcoal-making, and
            cultivation will be prevented or mitigated. The preservation
            of cultural property may be safeguard relevant to this project.

display_title.display_title:
Uganda - Second Northern Uganda
            Reconstruction Project : Environment and social management framework
